story: When Jackie Howard moved in with the Walter family in the premiere episode of "My Life With the Walter Boys," it was instantly apparent that they have a full house.

George and Katherine Walter (Marc Blucas and Sarah Rafferty) were already parents to eight children and taking care of two nephews when Jackie (Nikki Rodriguez) showed up. But despite having an already-chaotic household, the couple never hesitated to take Jackie in when her parents and sister died in an accident.
If you've seen Seasons 1 and 2 of the Netflix show, you know that Jackie falls into a love triangle with two of the Walter brothers: Cole and Alex (Noah LaLonde and Ashby Gentry, respectively).

In addition to living with them, Jackie attends high school with Walter brothers Cole, Alex, Nathan (Corey Fogelmanis) and Danny (Connor Stanhope), plus their cousins Lee (Myles Perez) and Isaac Garcia (Isaac Arellanes). While the majority of the Walter children are in high school, three of them — Jordan, Parker and Benny Walter — are younger.

While watching the show, you've likely found yourself questioning how old the Walter siblings and cousins are and where they fall in the family lineup. Below, we're breaking down the family tree to help you make sense of it all.
Will Walter — 26
Will Walter is the oldest Walter child. In Season 1, he's 25 and is living with his fiancée Hayley Young (Zoë Soul), and the couple get married by the end of the season.

By Season 2, Will is 26 and working closely with his father George and Jackie's uncle Richard (Alex Quijano) on a project to develop the Walter family farm into a tourist destination. Along the way, he clashes with his parents about the extent of the project.
Danny Walter — 17

Danny Walter is the twin brother of Cole Walter. In Season 1, he’s 16 years old. After Cole and his girlfriend Erin (Alisha Newton) break up, Danny grows close to her while rehearsing for the school play.

Fast forward to Season 2 and Danny is 17 years old. He’s secretly dating Erin but doesn’t want to tell Cole for fear that he’ll be upset. Eventually, Cole finds out. Danny and Erin run into some relationship drama along the way but agree to work things out at the end of Season 2.
Cole Walter – 17
Cole Walter, the twin brother of Danny, is somewhat of a heartbreaker around town and instantly has chemistry with Jackie when he meets her. He starts off the series as 16 years old.
In Season 2, Cole is 17 years old and starting to think about his life after high school. He's still pining over Jackie after they shared a kiss in the Season 1 finale.
Alex Walter – 16

Alex Walter is the same age as Jackie. They both start off the series at 15 years old and quickly fall for each other. In Season 1, Alex drinks a little too much at Will's wedding and tells Jackie he loves her. Later that night, she shares a kiss with Cole.

In Season 2, Alex is 16 years old and practicing to be a bull rider. He finds chemistry with his trainer, Blake Hartford (Natalie Sharp), but soon gets back together with Jackie and they start dating secretly.
Jackie Howard — 16

When we first meet Jackie in Season 1, she’s a 15-year-old living in New York City with her family. When they suddenly died in a car accident, she moves to Colorado to live with the Walters since Katherine was her mother’s close friend.
By Season 2, Jackie is 16 years old and preparing to get her driver’s license. She’s still adjusting to life in Colorado and tied up in a love triangle with Alex and Cole Walter.
Isaac Garcia — 16
Isaac Garcia is one of the Walter boys’ cousins who live with them while their father is deployed in the military. He’s 15 years old when the series begins.

In Season 2, Isaac is 16 years old and on the school's football team. When his teammate Dylan (Kolton Stewart) fails a drug test and decides to step aside and take responsibility for his mistakes, Isaac is tasked with taking on the role of quarterback.
Nathan Walter  — 15
Nathan Walter is 14 years old in Season 1. After Jackie starts hanging out with her classmate Skylar (Jaylan Evans), Nathan develops a crush on him. Over time, they start dating.

In Season 2, Nathan is 15 years old. He’s still dating Skylar but they break up after Nathan cheats with Skylar's ex, Zach (Carson MacCormac). Nathan and Zach end up calling it quits, but Skylar doesn't trust Nathan enough to get back together.
Lee Garcia — 15
Lee Garcia is Isaac's younger brother and one of the Walter boys' cousins who live with them. In Season 1, Lee is 14 years old. By Season 2, he's 15.
Jordan Walter - 13
Jordan Walter (Dean Petriw) is 12 years old in Season 1 of "My Life with the Walter Boys." He's often seen with his camera and pet snake Rumplesnakeskin. By Season 2, Jordan is 13 years old.
Parker Walter  — 10

Parker Walter (Alix West Lefler) is the only daughter in the Walter family, but she's very much one of the boys and gets along with her brothers. In Season 1, she's 9 years old. Over time, she warms up to Jackie.

In Season 2, Parker is 10 years old. She's annoyed with Jackie when she suddenly returns to the Walter family ranch after disappearing without notice for several months. After a heart-to-heart, though, Parker forgives her.
Benny Walter – 6

Benny Walter (Lennix James) is the youngest Walter child and begins the series as 5 years old. Like many children his age, he's a bit rambunctious. In Season 2, Benny is 6 years old. He's only seen on a few occasions in both seasons.

title: Kylie Kelce Shares Daughters' Reaction to Taylor Swift, Travis Kelce's Engagement
summary: Kylie Kelce has revealed her daughters' reaction to Taylor Swift's engagement to Travis Kelce and said they are "thrilled."
story: Kylie Kelce can’t wait to welcome to Taylor Swift to the family.
Kylie Kelce, who is married to Travis Kelce’s brother, Jason Kelce, has weighed in on what she and their four daughters think about their uncle's engagement to the pop icon.

“The girls are thrilled,” she told ABC News Sept. 5. “They’re so excited they’re getting another aunt. And we could not be more excited for them and what the future holds. We love love, and we love Taylor and Trav.”
Kylie and Jason Kelce got married in April 2018 and share daughters Wyatt, 5, Elliotte, 4, Bennett, 2, and Finn, 5 months.

Kylie Kelce is the latest member of the family to celebrate Travis Kelce's big news. Mom Donna Kelce changed her Facebook cover photo to include childhood photos of her son and Swift in the wake of their engagement. Dad Ed Kelce gave insight into the proposal in an interview, revealing that after Travis Kelce popped the question, the happy couple FaceTimed family.

Kylie Kelce had not yet spoken publicly about the engagement before now, but she did have a positive reaction after Swift appeared on the brothers’ “New Heights” podcast last month. During the episode, the “Blank Space” singer announced that her 12th studio album, “The Life of a Showgirl,” will come out Oct. 3.
That interview became the most-watched episode in the podcast's history, topping a mark previously set by Kylie Kylie. About two weeks later, Swift and Travis Kelce announced their engagement.

“Officially no longer the record holder for the most-watched episode of the other podcast. There’s no way it’s even close, and I love that for me,” Kylie Kylie said on the Aug. 14 episode of her own podcast, “Not Gonna Lie.”
Jason Kelce also addressed Swift taking the "New Heights" record.
“Sad news for the Kelce household. Kylie has been dethroned,” he playfully said. “We knew it was going to happen. Ky was holding strong.”

title: Macaulay Culkin Recalls John Candy's Response to His 'Monster' Father on Set
summary: Macaulay Culkin remembers John Candy looking out for him on set of "Uncle Buck," reflecting on Candy’s kindness amid challenges with his father Kit Culkin.
story: Macaulay Culkin was just 8 years old when he starred alongside the late John Candy in the 1989 comedy “Uncle Buck.”

Culkin, then a child actor, was accompanied on set by his father and former manager, Kit Culkin, from whom he would later sever ties. In the new documentary “John Candy: I Like Me,” he recalls how Candy was among the first to sense that something was off about his dad’s behavior, a dynamic that only worsened after the box-office success of “Home Alone” the following year.

“I think he always had that really great instinct. I think he saw. Listen, even before the wave crested and the 'Home Alone' stuff was happening, it was hard not to see how difficult my father was. It was no secret,” Culkin, 45, revealed in the film. “All of a sudden, the fame and the money came, and he became an infamous monster. He was already not a good guy.”

Culkin remembered Candy looking out for him, giving off what he described as “paternal” vibes: “I think John was looking a little side-eyed, like, ‘Is everything alright? You doing good? Good day? Everything’s alright? Everything’s good at home?”
For Culkin, the fact that there was an adult looking out for him meant a great deal and left a lasting impression.

“It doesn’t happen that often. It actually happened less as time went on,” Culkin shared. “I wish I got more of that in my life. It’s important that I remember that. I remember John caring when not a lot of people did.”
Candy was married to his wife, a ceramist and abstract painter, Rosemary Margaret Hobor, for 15 years. Together, they had two children, Chris and Jennifer
“He was the best dad,” Jennifer told TODAY.com in 2024. “He’d say, ‘Don’t worry what people think about you. Just be your authentic self.’”

title: Orlando Bloom Addresses Where Things Stand with Katy Perry After Breakup
summary: Orlando Bloom shared how he's doing in the wake of his breakup with his longtime partner, Katy Perry
story: Orlando Bloom shared how he's doing in the wake of his breakup with his longtime partner, Katy Perry.
Bloom, who's starring in the new boxing film "The Cut," said he is doing well on TODAY on Sept. 5 after he and Perry announced they had split in July.

"I'm great, man. I'm so grateful. We have the most beautiful daughter," Bloom said to TODAY's Craig Melvin. "You know, when you leave everything on the field, like I did in this movie, I feel grateful for all of it. And we're great. We're going to be great. It's nothing but love."
The pair welcomed their daughter, Daisy Dove, in August 2020, following their engagement in 2019.
Reps for Bloom, 48, and Perry, 40, issued a joint statement to TODAY.com on July 3 confirming the pair had ended their nearly 10-year, on-and-off relationship.

“Due to the abundance of recent interest and conversation surrounding Orlando Bloom and Katy Perry’s relationship, representatives have confirmed that Orlando and Katy have been shifting their relationship over the past many months to focus on co-parenting,” the statement said. “They will continue to be seen together as a family, as their shared priority is — and always will be — raising their daughter with love, stability and mutual respect.”

The pair first started dating in 2016, though they separated in 2017, before getting back together about a year later. Bloom proposed on Valentine's Day in 2019, but the couple had to postpone their wedding plans due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Perry announced her pregnancy in March 2020 in the music video for her song, “Never Worn White,” and welcomed her first child in August 2020.
Bloom is also dad to his son, Flynn, whom he shares with his ex-wife, model Miranda Kerr.
Kerr weighed in on Bloom and Perry's split in an interview on “Kyle & Jackie O” on Sept. 3, saying she recently spent time with the former couple in honor of their daughter's birthday on Aug. 26.
“I actually just saw them both on the weekend,” Kerr said. “We were celebrating Daisy’s birthday.”
“We’re one big, happy family,” she added. “Katy is amazing. I love her. And Orlando, obviously.”
Since the breakup, Perry has continued on with her "Lifetimes Tour," while Bloom has focused on his role in "The Cut," which premieres in theaters on Sept. 5.

title: Charlie Sheen, Denise Richards Have Rare Red Carpet Reunion Nearly 20 Years After Divorce
summary: Charlie Sheen and ex-wife Denise Richards reunited on the red carpet for the premiere of his Netflix documentary, “aka Charlie Sheen.” They share two daughters.
story: Charlie Sheen and ex-wife Denise Richards came together to help celebrate the premiere of Sheen’s new Netflix documentary, “aka Charlie Sheen.”
The couple posed for pictures together on the red carpet outside the Tudum Theater on Sept. 4, 2025, in Los Angeles. The pair hadn’t been on a red carpet together since 2005.

Sheen and Richards, who are parents to daughters Sami, 21, and Lola, 20, married in 2002 before she filed for divorce in 2005, amid intense media scrutiny and trouble at home. The marriage officially ended in 2006.

Sheen and Richards may not have been on a red carpet for two decades, but they shared the screen together more recently when Sheen appeared on an episode of Richards’ Bravo reality show, “Denise Richards & Her Wild Things,” in April with Lola.

“You know what’s so funny?” Lola told her parents while they had dinner at a restaurant. “I could never picture you guys being married. Sometimes I think about if you were still married and we all lived in the same house.”
“We would have had fun,” Richards said. “Right, Charles? We would’ve.”
“Sure, we would’ve,” Sheen concurred.
Richards, who filed for divorce from second husband Aaron Phypers in July, enjoyed the experience of getting together with Sheen and their daughter.
“I’m so glad we all had dinner. We should do it more often. People would think we’re f------ nuts saying that,” she said.
The "Young Guns" star has previously said he and Richards had managed to settle their differences.
“We’re absolutely friendly,” he told People in 2023.

“We went through so much s--- together that I don’t think either one of us has any energy left to be divisive,” he said. “The only thing that matters is the kids. We knew we had to park our nonsense and focus on the children, because they had nothing to do with any of our crud.”
Sheen reiterated how vital it was for them to make sure their kids remained their priority.

“Even in the hottest portions of depths of the inferno, we were still able to maintain a perspective that yes, the children need to come first,” he said. “Now we’re super friendly, and we’re actually able to process so much of it through humor these days.”
“aka Charlie Sheen” will be available to stream Sept. 10.

“Actor Charlie Sheen tells his story in this candid two-part documentary tracing his dazzling Hollywood rise, tabloid-topping fall and road to recovery,” Netflix says about the project, which features interviews with him, Richards and his other ex-wife Brooke Mueller. The two-part documentary also has interviews with Heidi Fleiss, Ramon Estevez and Sean Penn, as well as Sheen's “Two and a Half Men” co-star Jon Cryer, according to Tudum.

title: 'The Kelly Clarkson Show' Reveals Season 7 Premiere Date, Celebrity Guests
summary: “The Kelly Clarkson Show” is just weeks away from returning for its seventh season.
story: “The Kelly Clarkson Show” is just weeks away from returning for its seventh season.
The NBC talk show announced in a press release that it will resume filming for Season 7 next week starting Monday, Sept. 8, with new episodes set to begin airing Monday, Sept. 29.
The press release also revealed the group of celebrity guests who will appear in upcoming episodes, including Emily Blunt, Marion Cotillard and Colin Farrell.

Some more famous faces slated to make their way to Clarkson’s New York City set are Scarlett Johansson, Dwayne Johnson, Matthew McConaughey, Lionel Richie, Julia Roberts, Shonda Rhimes, Margot Robbie, Sylvester Stallone, Channing Tatum and Reese Witherspoon.

Viewers should expect an emotional return for the daytime talk show, as the press release revealed “Season 7 premiere week will spotlight the heroes who rescued campers from the devastating flood in Texas in July.”
But, fans can also anticipate a season filled with more joyful, music-filled moments that the show has become known for.

“This season fans can look forward to more entertaining panel interviews, exclusive celebrity moments, surprise musical performances and the return of the wildly popular ‘Kellyoke’ segment, where Clarkson highlights extraordinary emerging and established artists and delivers show-stopping covers of hits spanning every genre, backed by her band, Y’All,” the press release said.

title: Princess Diana's Hairdresser Slams Criticism of Kate Middleton's Hair
summary: Princess Diana's former hairstylist is slamming "evil" comments criticizing Catherine, Princess of Wales' new blond look
story: Princess Diana's former hairstylist is slamming "evil" comments criticizing Catherine, Princess of Wales' new blond look.

Sam McKnight, who was Diana’s hairstylist from 1990 until her tragic death in 1997, defended the former Kate Middleton after she debuted a longer blond hair style when she and husband Prince William visited the Natural History Museum in London on Sept. 4.

"I am shocked, horrified, dismayed and disgusted by all the nasty comments about the Princess of Wales today. A woman’s hair is very personal to her, it’s armour, defence, confidence and so much more," McKnight wrote in a message he posted the same day on Instagram.

“I cannot believe how evil and lacking in any kind of empathy are the comments, the majority made apparently by other women, attacking a vulnerable other young woman, who has no choice, by dint of who she married, and the role she took on, to bravely face the public," he continued.
McKnight went on to reference Kate’s 2024 cancer diagnosis in his message, saying he believed the mom of three would prefer to "be away from the public arena."

"She has brilliantly and quietly, unselfishly represented our country, the soft power we still have as a nation," he wrote, adding, "Cancer affects individuals differently, but is life-changing for everyone. So FFS LEAVE HER ALONE. SHAME ON YOU."
Kate announced in March 2024 that she had been diagnosed with an unspecified form of cancer.  She later shared in January 2025 that she was in remission.

The debut of Kate's new longer blond hair comes two months after she visited patients at a hospital in Essex, England, on July 2. While at the hospital, Kate spoke candidly to patients about her cancer journey.

“You put on a sort of brave face (with) stoicism through treatment. (When) treatment’s done, then it’s like, ‘I can crack on, get back to normal again,’” she said, according to video footage from the BBC.

“But," she added, "actually the phase afterwards is really difficult, you’re not necessarily under the clinical team any longer, but you’re not able to function normally at home as you perhaps once used to."

Cancer, she told the patients, can be hard on the patient and also his or her loved ones. "Through first diagnosis or post treatment and things like that, it is a life-changing experience both for the patient but also for the families as well," said Kate.

“You have to find your new normal and that takes time," she said, adding, "and it’s a rollercoaster. It’s not one smooth plane, which you expect it to be. But the reality is it’s not, you go through hard times."

title: ‘Golden Bachelor’ Season 2: Get to Know Mel Owens’ 23 Contestants
summary: The ladies of “The Golden Bachelor” Season 2 have arrived. Meet the 23 women competing to win Mel Owens' heart.
story: The ladies of “The Golden Bachelor” Season 2 have arrived!

On Sept. 4, a few weeks before the “Golden” spin-off returns for its sophomore season, ABC released the names of the contestants who will compete for Mel Owens’ heart. The network also released a video that shows each woman sharing fun facts about herself and explaining why she signed up for the show.
One contestant named Nicolle, a 64-year-old yoga instructor from Miami Beach, Florida, says in the clip about the “Golden” ladies, “I think we’re more beautiful, sexy, vibrant than ever.”

“The Golden Bachelor,” which debuted in 2023 with Gerry Turner as the first lead, follows contestants in their golden years looking for love. Season 2 will follow Mel, a newcomer to Bachelor Nation, as he dates women from ages 58 to 77. His season begins with a two-hour premiere on Wednesday, Sept. 24, at 8 p.m. ET on ABC.

Mel, a 66-year-old retired NFL player who now works as a lawyer, was announced as the season's leading man in April. But, he's since then sparked controversy after he said he wasn’t interested in dating women his own age.

“They asked me, ‘What’s your preferences?’ So I just said, ‘45 to 60,’ just being honest,” he said on the University of Michigan Athletics’ podcast, “In the Trenches,” in June. “And then the process went and I was selected and then we had lunch with the executive producer. I said, ‘You know, if they’re 60 or over, I’m cutting them.’”
He also said, “They got to be fit because I’m staying in shape and work out and stuff. And I told them, ‘Try to stay away from the artificial hips and the wigs.’”
He later revealed in an interview with Glamour that he apologized to the contestants for his remarks during the first night of filming.

“I apologized to the women on the show. When I first walked in, I addressed it. I apologized to them. I said, ‘It was unfair, insensitive. I want to earn it back. Just give me the chance.’ And hopefully, these last two weeks I earned some of that back,’” said Owens, who was in the middle of filming at the time.

How will they react? We’ll have to wait until the first episode airs to find out. For now, meet the 23 “Golden” ladies hoping to receive a rose from Mel Owens. Plus, learn what they reveal about themselves in the introduction video and in their official bios.
The Cast of ‘The Golden Bachelor’ Season 2...
Alexandra, 67
Occupation: Luxury yacht sales representative
Hometown: Miami, Florida
More about Alexandra: “If I am attracted to the brain of the gentleman, I’m attracted to everything else,” Alexandra said. “If he holds my hand and I feel butterflies, we have a great future.”
Amy, 63
Occupation: Full-time mom
Hometown: Short Hills, New Jersey
More about Amy: Amy is a “momager” to her twin daughters, who are “internet-famous,” according to her ABC bio. Outside of work, she likes to exercise, cook and dance.
Andra, 77
Occupation: Retired federal worker
Hometown: Los Angeles, California

More about Andra: If Andra looks familiar to members of Bachelor Nation, that's because she is the twin sister of “Golden Bachelor” Season 1 fan-favorite Sandra Mason. Andra enjoys crafting, spending time with her grandson, going to the gym and any adrenaline-filled activity.
Carla, 62
Occupation: Former model
Hometown: Los Angeles, California

More about Carla: Carla is a big believer in chemistry at first sight but said finding a connection in Los Angeles has been challenging. In her free time, she likes to read autobiographies and travel. She previously went on a solo safari in Tanzania.
Carol, 63
Occupation: Family manager for Los Angeles Dodgers star Freddie Freeman, her nephew
Hometown: Villa Park, California
More about Carol: Carol enjoys hiking, listening to Bad Bunny and playing the tambourine. She is a mom of three daughters and recently returned to college.
Cheryl, 66
Occupation: Retired from the IRS
Hometown: Englewood, Colorado
More about Cheryl: “My spirit is still young,” Cheryl said. “I race motocross.”
Cindy, 60
Occupation: Retired biomedical engineer
Hometown: Austin, Texas
More about Cindy: “We have a lot of living to do, and I’m looking for a partner to join me,” Cindy says about her golden years.
Debbie, 65
Occupation: Fitness professional
Hometown: Denver, Colorado

More about Debbie: “One of my proudest accomplishments is my fitness program,” Debbie said in her intro video. She described her program as “one of the longest-selling info commercials in history.” She also shared that she “absolutely believes in love at first sight.”
Diane, 71
Occupation: Librarian
Hometown: Wasilla, Alaska
More about Diane: Diane plays women’s hockey, has won three triathlons and is a huge Dolly Parton fan.
Gerri, 64
Occupation: Home care agency CEO
Hometown: Rockville, Maryland

More about Gerri: Gerri has dedicated her life to working in the health care industry for over 35 years, including being an ICU nurse during the COVID-19 pandemic. She is a proud mom and grandmother who likes to fish and play with her teacup Yorkie named Godiva.
Lily, 72
Occupation: Retired elementary school teacher
Hometown: Pacific Palisades, California
More about Lily: Lily wants her love story to resemble a romance novel. She hopes that her future partner likes to dance as she performs with a dance troupe called the Ole Skool Crew.
Lisa, 66
Occupation: State park employee
Hometown: Marion, Ohio

More about Lisa: As a state park employee, Lisa is passionate about taking care of animals and has rescued multiple cats. She is ready to leave her small town, where she describes dating as “nonexistent,” and see if Mel Owens is the one for her.
Maia, 58
Occupation: College sports consultant
Hometown: Malibu, California

More about Maia: “What do I say to those people? You’re crazy!” she responded when asked about how she would react to someone who says she is too old to find love. In her spare time, Maia can be found playing pickleball, going to concerts and driving up the California coast.
Monica B., 62
Occupation: Flight attendant
Hometown: Huntsville, Alabama
More about  Monica B.: When she isn’t flying all over the world, Monica B. spends her days caring for her four grandchildren, visiting farmers markets and doing yoga in the park.
Monica P., 60
Occupation: Cosmetic dentist
Hometown: Birmingham, Alabama
More about Monica P.: Monica P. likes to spend her time snow skiing, water skiing, singing karaoke, playing board games and going to Pilates classes.
Mylene, 61
Occupation: Casino VIP host
Hometown: Las Vegas, Nevada

More about Mylene: Mylene was born and raised in the Philippines before she relocated to Japan and eventually made her way to Las Vegas. She is a fan of Bruno Mars and would love to go skydiving one day.
Nicolle, 64
Occupation: Yoga teacher
Hometown: Miami Beach, Florida

More about Nicolle: When asked by a producer how she would reply to critics who think she is “too old for love,” Nicolle had an honest response. “You know, what I want to say is f--- them,” she replied before flipping off the camera with both hands. She laughed and added, “But that’s not what I’m going to say.”
Peg, 62
Occupation: Retired firefighter and bomb tech
Hometown: Las Vegas, Nevada
More about Peg: Peg was a firefighter for 22 years before spending 13 years defusing bombs. “So, Mel doesn’t scare me,” she cheekily said.
Robin, 63
Occupation: Wealth adviser/ Vineyard owner
Hometown: Napa Valley, California
More about Robin: Robin likes to watch football, ride her motorcycle and tap dance. She also started her own wine label.
Roxanne, 62
Occupation: Longevity nurse
Hometown: Austin, Texas
More about Roxanne: Roxanne said that getting older is all about gaining wisdom. “Even though I am 62, I am full of life,” she said.
Susie, 62
Occupation: Realtor
Hometown: Del Mar, California
More about Susie: Susie said she believes, “Life begins in the golden years.” The mom of three is looking for a spontaneous man who wants to travel.
Terri, 71
Occupation: Cosmetic dentist
Hometown: Houston, Texas

More about Terri: Terri said that she views her golden years as still having her whole life ahead of her. She is a longtime “Bachelor” fan and has watched the show since it began in 2002. She also taught herself to be a ventriloquist and studied zoology in college.
Tracy, 62
Occupation: Interior designer
Hometown: Lafayette, Louisiana
More about Tracy: Tracy loves to dance, with one of her favorite styles being the Jitterbug. Her style icon is Audrey Hepburn.

title: Legendary Rock Group Offers to Be Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce’s Wedding Band
summary: Foreigner wrote an Instagram post offering to serve as the wedding band at Taylor Swift's wedding to Travis Kelce.
story: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce could go from "Anti-Hero" to "Juke Box Hero."
Foreigner has announced it would be happy to serve as the wedding band for the couple, who set off a frenzy after they announced their engagement last month.
“An open letter to @taylorswift and @killatrav…” the band captioned a note it posted on its Instagram page on Sept. 3.

“Dear Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce, we know what love is,” the post began, alluding to the band's 1984 megahit “I Want to Know What Love Is,” which earned a Grammy nomination for best pop performance by a duo or group with vocal.
“We spent 40 years figuring it out ... and now you guys have too,” the band continued. “Please accept this as our formal offer to be your wedding band. Best wishes, Foreigner.”
The prospect of Foreigner playing the wedding was met with widespread reaction.
“😂😂😂😂😂,” Flavor Flav wrote in the comments.
“Wow this is amazing, what a gift!!! Hope they accept!! I definitely would! 😍,” another person wrote.
“Oh my goodness please do this y’all,” begged one fan.
“Y’all are too cool for them! Come on,” someone else commented.
“Taylor and Travis are celebrities, you’re Legends,” raved another person.

Aside from “I Want to Know What Love Is,” Foreigner’s stable of hits includes “Waiting for a Girl Like You,” “Juke Box Hero,” “Hot Blooded,” “Urgent” and “Feels Like the First Time.” The band was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2024 after a push from other artists who voiced their support.
Foreigner is keeping busy these days, too. The band is currently touring the United States and will head to Europe next June for nearly a month’s worth of dates.
There’s no word whether Swift and Kelce plan to look at the offer and shake it off or if they’re actually into making Foreigner part of their love story.

title: Jamie Lee Curtis Shares the 1 Thing Her Husband 'Cooks' For Her: 'Our Love Language'
summary: Christopher Guest only knows how to make one simple sandwich, according to Jamie Lee Curtis.
story: Christopher Guest only knows how to make one simple sandwich, according to Jamie Lee Curtis.
Luckily it's her favorite one.
Curtis shared on "The Late Show" with Stephen Colbert on Sept. 3 that her husband of 40 years may be limited in the kitchen, but he knows the perfect way to her heart.
She was asked during a segment what she thinks is the best kind of sandwich.
"Peanut butter and jelly," she said. "PB&J. It is the only thing Christopher Guest knows how to make. It is our love language."
Curtis, 66, and Guest, 77, celebrated their 40th wedding anniversary in December 2024.

The Oscar-winning actor and the director of “Best in Show” and “Waiting for Guffman” have made laughter a central feature of their long-lasting relationship. She said on TODAY in 2024 that Guest still makes her laugh “more than any human being."
“I’m sure there’s something about me that he likes. I don’t know what it is, but I’m sure there’s something,” she joked.
The parents of two got married only months after Curtis first saw a picture of Guest in Rolling Stone magazine in 1984.
“I said out loud to my friend, the late, great Debra Hill, ‘Oh, I’m going to marry that guy,'" Curtis said in Interview Magazine.
She then ran into him at a restaurant and they had their first date.
“It was a moment of just knowing. This feeling of, ‘This is the real thing,’ and knowing that,” Guest said on Nick Offerman and Megan Mullally’s podcast.
While the two do enjoy a good PB&J sandwich, that might be one of the few things they have in common.

“My husband and I are opposites. We have been for 33 years, and we always will be,” Curtis told Good Housekeeping in 2018. “He’s an intellectual, and I was from the movie star/alcoholic/drug addict side, where ­education was not the most important thing. We don’t listen to the same radio station, we don’t read the same paper, we don’t go to bed at the same time.”

title: 'The Paper' Season 1 Ending Leaves Relationships Up in the Air
summary: "The Paper" is a spinoff of "The Office," with a new team of personalities including Ned, Esmeralda, Mare and Oscar. Find out what happens in the Season 1 finale.
story: Spoilers ahead for the Season 1 finale of “The Paper”
It’s the biggest night in journalism — in Ohio to be exact, and “The Paper”s revitalized Toledo Truth Teller is nominated for three awards.

Created by the man behind “The Office” Greg Daniels and Michael Koman (“Nathan For You”), “The Paper” is a Peacock mockumentary series about a group of dedicated journalists who — led by an optimistic editor-in-chief, Ned Sampson, played by Domhnall Gleeson — aim to save their local newspaper from turning into a worthless pile of clickbait articles.

The 10-episode sitcom introduces a new crew of personalities, each trying their best to contribute, while one in particular is unafraid to sabotage Ned's efforts: managing editor Esmeralda, played by Sabrina Impacciatore.
Ahead of its premiere, it was announced that the show was picked up for a second season.
Here is what happens in the Season 1 finale of “The Paper.”
The Toledo Truth Teller Is Nominated at the Ohio Journalism Awards, Chaos Ensues

In the Season 1 finale, Mare (Chelsea Frei) is nominated for an Ohio Journalism Award for her piece on the Softies clog, Ned for the Truth Teller and Oscar (Oscar Nuñez) for best new game for his Mr. Digit Puzzle.

While Mare and Oscar can’t contain their excitement at the Ohio Journalism Awards, Ned keeps reminding his staff that he doesn’t care about winning — even though he’s obsessively rubbing a “rabbit’s foot” made from a childhood stuffy for good luck. His anxieties are made worse after Mare introduces popular YouTube star Theo (Chris Witaske) as her date.

When Ken (Tim Key) and Esmeralda discover they’re not sitting at the same table as their publisher Marv (Allan Harvey), they’re both slighted. Fearing for his job, Ken makes a point to “save” Marv by the end of the night, going so far as engineering a way to provoke him to choke.
Unfortunately for Ken, Oscar is the hero who gives both Marv and his brother the Heimlich. Since Esmeralda also wasn’t nominated for any awards that evening, she feels snubbed on both accounts.

After Mare and Oscar both win, Esmeralda decides to steal the spotlight during the award show’s in memoriam and sings an impromptu song about the “sad, dead journalists” who made their “final deadline.”

Viewers may recognize Impacciatore from Season 2 of “White Lotus” as the stern resort manager Valentina. If you thought Valentina gave Mia and Lucia a hard time at the hotel, Impacciatore says Valentina would not stand one bit for Esmeralda’s flair for dramatics.

“Valentina wouldn’t even allow Esmeralda to get in,” Impacciatore tells TODAY.com, while discussing how these two characters would interact. “But Esmeralda would for sure try to find a way to take the place of Valentina.”
One Relationship Ends on a Low Point

Nicole (Ramona Young) discovers that her situationship with Detrick (MelvinGregg) isn't so casual. She finds out that he isn’t dating anyone else and feels tricked into a monogamous relationship. Upset with Nicole’s commitment issues, Detrick breaks up with her. Nicole argues they weren’t in a true relationship to justify an actual breakup, but Detrick counters that it was real to him.
Speaking with TODAY.com, Ramona Young says what excited her most about her character’s relationship with Detrick throughout the season was the nuances it brought.

“I like the unknown and the messiness of it,” Young says, adding it gave her the chance to explore a new acting point of view since her past roles tended to be her pinning after others, not the other way around. “It’s interesting to play a different perspective as an actor and wrap my head around something unfamiliar.”
Though Nicole and Detrick’s relationship ends at a low point in the finale, Gregg shares an optimistic, yet realistic viewpoint for their characters.
“I hope they find clarity, but Detrick’s heart is going to come at a price in season two,” Gregg says. “She’s going to have to work for it.”
Ned and Mare Explore Their Feelings for Each Other
All season long, tension grew between Ned and Mare.

Wanting to help her editor-in-chief prepare his acceptance speech, Mare ushers him away from the ceremony where they stumble upon a wedding reception. Ned practices his speech as they hit the dance floor, but when the bride and groom kick them out for crashing, they lose hotel access and are locked out. As luck would have it, Ned is nowhere in sight when the Ohio Journalism Awards announce his win for outstanding print coverage.

Seizing the opportunity, Ken and Esmeralda accept on his behalf. Though, no one can understand them because they spend the whole time talking over each other. Before Ken and Esmeralda can get into a fight over the award, Ned arrives and starts delivering a heartfelt speech — that is, until Esmeralda “faints.” Don’t worry, she’s fine. In fact, the documentary crew catches her smiling as everyone rushes to her side.

At the end of the night, Oscar shares relationship advice with Ned that makes him reconsider telling Mare how he really feels. Soon after, Ned rushes to Mare’s door and hands her the speech he wrote. Mare says it’s not a good time, leading Ned to assume she's still with Theo. However, she reveals it’s because Nicole is crying in her hotel room over her breakup with Detrick.

In the end, Ned and Mare’s journalistic integrity kicks in and they decide they must kiss for research purposes, hoping if they “get it out of the way,” they could go back to being friends. But if Ned’s “oh, s---” response tells us anything, it’s that there is a lot more to unpack come Season 2.
Frei, who plays Mare, tells TODAY.com her and Gleeson’s final scene could have ended without any lip action.

“Because Donald’s character is so by the book and wants to be a good boss, we filmed it a million different ways. They kiss. They didn’t kiss. They get into a fight,” she says of the different approaches. “So it was really cool to see that (the directors) ended up choosing the kiss.”
For Frei, Chelsea's budding romance with Ned reminded her of another relationship in her life.

“It’s funny because my parents met on a construction site,” Frei says. “My dad was the boss, and my mom was the secretary. I know it’s ridiculous, but they’re still together over 30 years later. So, what are you going to do? It works.”
Fans will get to see in Season 2 of “The Paper” if Ned and Mare’s relationship has what it takes to follow suit.

title: Cause of Death Revealed for Annabelle Doll Handler Dan Rivera
summary: A cause of death for Dan Rivera, the paranormal investigator who died in a Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, hotel room while on tour with the allegedly haunted Annabelle doll, has been determined
story: A cause of death for Dan Rivera, the paranormal investigator who died in a Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, hotel room while on tour with the allegedly haunted Annabelle doll, has been determined.
Rivera, 54, died July 13, 2025 of natural causes as a result of heart issues, according to a press release from the Adams County Coroner’s Office obtained by TODAY.com.
“Mr. Rivera had a known history of cardiac issues, which were consistent with the findings,” said Adams County Coroner Francis Dutrow in a statement.
Dutrow also confirmed the Annabelle doll, which is rumored to be possessed by evil spirits, "was not present in the room" at the time of Rivera's passing.
What Are Cardiac Issues?
Cardiac issues can be caused by heart disease, which is a range of conditions that affect the heart, according to the Mayo Clinic.
Heart disease includes:

Blood vessel disease, such as coronary artery diseaseIrregular heartbeats, called arrhythmiasHeart conditions that you’re born with, called congenital heart defectsDisease of the heart muscleHeart valve disease
Blood vessel disease, such as coronary artery disease
Irregular heartbeats, called arrhythmias
Heart conditions that you’re born with, called congenital heart defects
Disease of the heart muscle
Heart valve disease
What Was Rivera Doing with the Annabelle Doll?

At the time of his death, Rivera had been participating in the “Devils on the Run Tour,” a traveling exhibition hosted by the New England Society For Psychic Research, a Connecticut-based paranormal research group.

The tour honors the work of the group's founders, supernatural investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren, and features displays of allegedly haunted artifacts from the Warrens' Occult Museum in Monroe, Connecticut.
As part of the tour, the infamous Annabelle doll, a red-headed Raggedy Ann doll, was making a visit to Gettysburg when Rivera died.
Why Do People Think Annabelle Is Possessed?

In 1968, the Warrens began investigating the case of the Annabelle doll, which a nursing student brought home to the apartment she shared with a roommate after receiving the doll as a gift, according to a timeline on the NESPR website
The roommates soon began noticing "strange occurrences" with the doll. They met with a medium who told them the doll was “inhabited by the spirit of a young girl named Annabelle,” the website states.
“The two roommates tried to accept the doll’s spirit and please it only to have it reciprocate maliciousness and violent intent,” the NESPR website site states.
The Warrens believed that Annabelle was “demonically possessed,” according to the website. “They removed the doll from the house and encased it in a glass box to contain the evil spirited entity.”
A doll named Annabelle appeared in the 2013 movie “The Conjuring,” which was based on one of the Warrens’ real-life investigation.
The 2014 movie “Annabelle” went on to delve into the doll’s backstory, though it altered key details from the account shared by the New England Society For Psychic Research.
That movie inspired two prequels: “Annabelle: Creation” and “Annabelle Comes Home.”

title: EXCLUSIVE: David Duchovny Reveals What Left Him Feeling Unsettled About 'The X-Files'
summary: David Duchovny opens up about his new poetry book, "About Time," parenthood and what part of "The X-Files" left him feeling unsettled.
story: With a list of credits a mile long, it’s tempting to wonder if there’s anything David Duchovny can’t do.

The four-time Emmy-nominated actor and director has appeared in dozens of TV shows and movies; fronts his own alternative rock band; hosts a podcast; and has had seven books published, including his latest effort, “About Time,” a book of Duchovny’s collected poetry.

“It was a way for me ... to try and talk about things that felt almost too deep for words, almost like journaling, but before we journaled,” Duchovny tells Savannah Guthrie and Willie Geist during a recent appearance on Jenna & Friends.

Despite being his first published book in the genre, “The X-Files” star says he’s been writing poetry since he was a teen. He eventually parlayed that love of prose into an English literature degree from Princeton University, as well as earning a master's from Yale University. In the process, Duchovny picked up an honorable mention nod from the Academy of American Poets for his work.

“They sent me a plaque,” Duchovny tells TODAY.com during a sit-down interview. “But, oddly, as I was getting up early yesterday morning to come from LA to (New York) and was reaching around in the dark for things that I needed, I knocked over this plaque and I broke it.”
“So, I thought, ‘Is this a good omen or bad omen?’ We don’t know,” Duchovny says with a laugh.
Either way, “About Time” is a catharsis of sorts for the actor who says he’s always looking for new means of “servicing the inspiration,” which he says he’s fortunate to have plenty of.

“Why I find myself doing many different things, I think, is because I’m constantly trying to express something, and I’m looking for the best vessel to do that in,” Duchovny says about deciding on which outlet works best for channeling his feelings and ideas.

“It usually starts in language, and that leads into acting, directing, poetry, fiction, writing,” he explains. “So, it’s really just finding different ways because the form is going to influence the expression. And I find that to be interesting.”
‘Life Is a Game’

At 65, Duchovny is celebrating his recent marriage to longtime girlfriend Monique Pendleberry. Prior to Pendleberry, he was married for nearly two decades to Téa Leoni, with whom he shares two children: West, 26, and Kyd, 23.
When asked what he hopes he’s imparted on his children, Duchovny ponders for a moment before answering, “I think to take away the sense that life is just game, it doesn’t mean anything.”
Not that life is trivial, he clarifies, but rather he hopes his kids take things seriously — but not too seriously.
“There’s a sense in which you want your kids to find their passion,” says Duchovny, who explains that having passion is good, unless it prevents you from keeping an open mind to other possibilities.
“I’m always saying, that’s not the world. There’s many different worlds. But, yes, find the thing that turns you on. So, I’m giving them very bad advice, I’m giving contradictory advice.”
It makes no sense to try and relive, relitigate or redo because you can’t.
David Duchovny
In reflecting on his own life, would he do anything differently if he could go back and do it all again?
“Well, I can’t,” he says. “And it makes no sense to try and relive, relitigate or redo because you can’t.”
Instead, he prefers to focus on the philosophy behind failure, the subject of his popular podcast, “Fail Better,” which he launched in 2024.
In the Q&A podcast, Duchovny interviews newsmakers like Bette Midler, Ben Stiller and Amanda Knox about how perceived failure can actually be the catalyst for opportunity and personal growth.
“We don’t know when we’re on the right road. Most of the time, we just know we’re on some kind of road and we have some kind of goal,” he says about the concepts of success and failure.

“Failure towards an imperfect goal or a wrong goal or whatever you think you’re going or doing can be a good thing. So, failure and success are really, at this point, I don’t see them as meaningful. They’re just snapshots in time. What could be a success is actually a failure waiting to happen and vice versa.”
On ‘The X-Files’: ‘They Really Had a Crystal Ball’

On the subject of success, one of Duchovny’s notable accomplishments is his turn as FBI agent Fox Mulder on the hit show “The X-Files.” The sci-fi program, which originally ran from 1993-2002 before reboots in 2016 and 2018, launched his career and made the actor a household name.

Through the decades, he’s left and returned to the franchise, as well as appeared in the series’ two feature films, “The X-Files” and “The X-Files: I Want to Believe,” released in 1998 and 2008, respectively.
Known for its spooky UFO and paranormal themes, was there ever an episode that left Duchovny feeling particularly unsettled?

“Sometimes I think back, and I said this to (series creator) Chris Carter, 'I think you really were kind of Nostradamus in a way. You really saw a lot of what’s going on, a lot of the conspiratorial thinking and stuff like that happen.' So, it’s not really one episode, but I’m just kind of amazed at that writers room, which included Vince Gilligan, Jim Wong, Darin Morgan, Glen Morgan, Howard Gordon. This was a heavy-hitting writers room, and they really had a crystal ball.”
‘I’m Not Content Ever’
In addition to his latest book, Duchovny says he’s also just wrapped a new album, though he’s not sure when it’ll be released.
It’s the fourth for the actor-musician whose other albums include his 2015 debut, “Hell or Highwater,” “Every Third Thought,” released in 2018, as well as the 2021 album “Gestureland.”
With so many projects on his plate, it begs the question: Does Duchovny have unfinished business?
“No,” he says without hesitating. “No. There’s just more business.”
Even so, it doesn’t mean he’s static.

“I’m not content ever. It’s good to have a new thing to do or to have a new project because they all have different hurdles. They all have different problems to solve. And that’s when you get creative is when you’re solving problems.”

title: Denzel Washington Reveals How We’re Really Supposed to Say His Name
summary: Denzel Washington explains on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” the proper pronunciation of his first name and how his mother changed the way to say it.
story: There’s only one Denzel Washington. Actually, there’s only one Den-ZELL Washington.
The two-time Academy Award-winning actor has revealed that people do not properly pronounce his first name, while also explaining the right way to say it.

The revelation came after Jimmy Kimmel told him there are multiple players in the NFL named Denzel when Washington appeared Sept. 2 on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” That led the “Training Day” star to explain he knows the players are named in his honor because of how Denzel is pronounced.
“And this is how you know they named themselves after me, because my name’s not pronounced ‘Den-ZELL,’” Washington said. “My name’s pronounced ‘Den-ZULL.’
“I’m Den-ZULL Jr. My father’s Den-ZULL Hayes Washington Sr. I’m Den-ZULL Hayes Washington Jr.”
How to Pronounce Denzel Washington

Washington is one of the preeminent actors of his generation, with eight other Oscar nominations beyond his two wins, but long before he conquered the big screen he was just another Denzel in his home growing up.
He claims having the same first name as his dad created confusion, prompting his mother to find a way to fix the situation.
“My mother would say, ‘Den-ZULL!’ And we’d both show up,” he said. “So she said, ‘From now on, you’re ‘Den-ZELL.’ That’s how it got pronounced ‘Den-ZELL.’”
Washington is not alone when it comes to celebrities with names that people say incorrectly.
Last month, Kirsten Dunst told Town & Country magazine that “everyone messes up” her name.
“I give up. I don't care,” she said. “I’ll answer to ‘KRIS-ten,’ ‘KIR-sten’ or ‘KIER-sten,’ which is how you say my name, but I don’t blame people,” she said.
Dan Levy and his father, Eugene Levy, also joked about how to pronounce their last name while hosting the Emmy Awards in 2024.
“If it goes well tonight, my name is pronounced ‘LEH-vee,’ not ‘LEE-vee,’” Dan Levy joked during their monologue.
Former presidential candidate Kamala Harris has also dealt with people mispronouncing her name, as have other celebrities, including Rob McElhenney, Halle Bailey, Zendaya and Rihanna.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Julie Chrisley Opens Up About the Family Milestones She Missed Behind Bars
summary: Todd, Julie and Savannah Chrisley talk to TODAY.com about life after prison, their new show and what they wish they didn't miss out on while away.
story: Todd and Julie Chrisley’s imprisonment has defined the family’s last two years.
The couple has since been pardoned and released, returning home to their children and living in the limelight, but it hasn’t been easy.

Now, they — along with their daughter Savannah Chrisley, sons Chase and Grayson Chrisley, and more family members — are sharing what happened during their time in prison and how life has changed since their releases in a new Lifetime series, “The Chrisleys: Back to Reality,” which aired in two parts on Sept. 1 and 2.

“We’ve stepped back into it the way that we know how to step back into it, but it’s certainly different. This time, we’re different,” Todd Chrisley tells TODAY.com. “We’ve gone through a lot, and I don’t think that you can go through what we’ve gone through and come back and be the same — and if you do, you probably should go back.”
He continues, “Everyone’s different. Everyone has grown in different ways. And there’s pain and there’s hurt and there’s so much emotions that have to be unpacked.”
What Happened to Julie and Todd Chrisley?
Todd and Julie Chrisley were indicted in 2019 on 12 counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit bank fraud and conspiracy to defraud the United States, according to documents obtained by NBC News.

Convicted on federal fraud charges in 2022, Todd Chrisley was originally sentenced to 12 years in prison, with Julie Chrisley receiving a seven-year sentence, according to the U.S. attorney’s office. Their sentences were then slightly shortened by two years and 14 months, respectively.

As the pair reported to their respective prisons in January 2023, Savannah Chrisley took charge, advocating for her family's release, appealing the decision and caring for her underage brother Grayson and niece Chloe.
The two-part Lifetime special shows how Savannah Chrisley took over as head of the household and the struggles she faced. It also includes personal calls from Todd and Julie Chrisley while in prison.

“I think it’s hard because when they were away, I like to say, ‘You’re in there, all you have to deal with is what happens in those walls.’ Meanwhile, we’re on the outside having to deal with everything else. There was so much that happened, so much said that they have no idea about,” she tells TODAY.com, adding that the show highlights “the anger and resentment” towards other family members “because we were living in so much chaos.”

Amid Savannah Chrisley’s efforts to do anything and everything to help her parents, President Donald Trump pardoned her parents. They received the news in May of this year, and the “Chrisley Knows Best” stars were released from their respective prisons on May 28.
What do the Chrisleys wish they hadn’t missed while in prison?
Todd Chrisley is well aware that his daughter “gave up two-and-a-half years of her life” and hopes she can now go back to living her life as a 28-year-old.
The parents don’t take it for granted that they got a second chance, but wish they could’ve been there for special and once-in-a-lifetime family moments.
“There were so many life moments that I wish I could have been there for,” Julie Chrisley tells TODAY.com.
“Grayson graduated high school, he went to college. Chloe went to middle school. Savannah went through a breakup. Nic (Kerdiles) passed away while we were in prison.”

She continues, “There were so many of those moments that we should have been there for our children, but unfortunately, we weren’t. So all we can do now is do what we’ve always done, just be there when we can be.”
Todd Chrisley adds that, yes, they were gone for about 28 months but that doesn’t erase the years they were present before — and now, again, after.

“I think that when you talk about what is the one moment — I think that question really belongs to our children. I don’t think it really belongs to us,” he says. “Only they know what was that particular moment that they felt like they needed us most.”
The Moment Savannah Chrisley Missed Her Mom the Most
While it was especially hard for Savannah Chrisley to navigate a world without her parents, she says, there was one instance she wishes she could have her mom at her side.
She and Nic Kerdiles, a former NHL player, got engaged in 2018, before calling it off in 2020. The athlete died in a motorcycle accident on Sept. 23, 2023.
She then dated and broke up with Robert Shiver, a man whose wife was charged with attempting to murder him, while her parents were in prison.

“I know for me, I will never forget going through my breakup,” Savannah Chrisley says. “My mom called me as much as she possibly could that day, and she would call and I would be crying or this or that. I like to say, nothing prepares you for your first real adult breakup and not being able to pick up the phone and call your mom.”
She says it was little things like that “that were extremely difficult.”

“Or if I had a question with Chloe or Grayson, or just dealing with all the adversities that I had to deal with out here because there was so much stress that I wish they could have just been here to take it off of me,” she continues. “But I was able to get through it, and I feel like I came out stronger, more equipped to deal with life and hardship, so I wouldn’t trade it for the world.”
Todd Chrisley says that their daughter “sheltered” them from the struggles that she faced, saying,

“As a parent and you see your child hurting, I don’t know that I would have been able to have dealt with that being in prison, knowing that she was having that kind of struggle. And I think that’s why she kept so much away from us.”
Todd Chrisley SaysThe Next 20 Years Belong to Them

Todd and Julie Chrisley, who have been married since 1996, were also kept away from each other, unable to speak on the phone for more than two years — the longest stretch without hearing each other’s voices in their three decades together.
“We were never able to speak for 28 months because the warden where I was at would not allow it,” Todd Chrisley says, with Julie Chrisley adding they were able to email.
“However, there was a two, three day response lag time, and so it was hard to keep a conversation going,” she says. “You pretty much had to just keep it very surface.”
As for how prison has strengthened their marriage, they both remained committed to each other through the good and the bad.

“I knew the day that I met Julie that that’s who God sent to me,” he says. “You come back and you look at each other and you have to have the hard conversations. You have to be able to say to each other, ‘You know, we signed up for this 30 years ago. Are we both still as committed to this today as we were then?’ And both of us unanimously said we’re not going anywhere. This is our life.”
Calling her his “safe place,” he says, “I want to be that safe place for her.”

“This is mine and Julie’s first chapter of our life that we will truly be able to just be husband and wife,” he says. “And we will be a parent to all of our children, but we only have Chloe at home. We’ve never been parents to just one child in the house. We’ve never been able to just pick up and go if we wanted to go. And this next because I say ... that the next 20 years belong to me and Julie.”

title: ‘The Paper’ Reveals What Happened to Dunder Mifflin After ‘The Office’
summary: Peacock’s ‘The Paper’ reveals the fate of Dunder Mifflin and how ‘The Office’ storyline connects to the new mockumentary series.
story: Warning: Spoilers ahead for “The Paper”
“The Paper” briefly took viewers back to Scranton, Pennsylvania, home of Dunder Mifflin and “The Office” crew.

The new 10-episode Peacock series created by “The Office” creator Greg Daniels and Michael Koman (“Nathan For You”), continues with the mockumentary style that fans grew to love over the years. Ahead of its premiere, “The Paper” was already renewed for a second season.
The American version of “The Office” ran for nine seasons from 2005 to 2013 on NBC, becoming an Emmy-winning series and staple in pop culture history.

“The Paper” follows a whole new team, led by Ned Samson (Domhnall Gleeson), editor-in-chief of the Toledo Truth Teller newspaper. Ned and his reporters attempt to save the dying historic Midwestern newspaper, all while giving viewers light-hearted and comical moments and, of course, camera stares.
But before the camera crew digs into the lives of the Toledo, Ohio, team, they explain what happened to Dunder Mifflin.
How Does ‘The Paper’ Address ‘The Office’?
The first episode of “The Paper” begins with a message about “The Office” team.

“In 2005, a documentary crew started filming at a paper company in Scranton, Pennsylvania,” it says on the screen, before it shows the office building. “They followed the workers in an average office, dealing with new rules of workplace behavior and the ups and downs of their personal lives.”

“Twenty years later, they returned,” it reads, showing the businesses still in operation at Scranton Business Park: Vance Refrigeration, Ruben’s Electrical Contractors, Kavala Data Filters and One and Done Laser.
Cameras then pan to the first cameo from “The Office” cast: Bob Vance (Robert Ray Shafer) of Vance Refrigeration and still married to Dunder Mifflin employee Phyllis Vance (Phyllis Smith).
Chatting with the documentary crew, Bob tells them Dunder Mifflin has “been gone for a while.”
“Phil and Stanley keep in touch, we both have Schnoodles. Awesome dogs,” Bob says. “Other than that, the One and Done guys are fine. Less drama, that’s for sure.”
What Happened to Dunder Mifflin?
As Bob shares an update on Dunder Mifflin, it’s revealed that the One and Done Laser company took over the office space that once included Michael Scott (Steve Carell) and the paper supply team.
Bob then searches the Chamber of Commerce to get the details about what happened to Dunder Mifflin.

“They keep a list of every business that’s closed in the last 10 years. Ha, there it is. Dunder Mifflin, says purchased by Enervate in Toledo, Ohio, in 2019,” he reads from the website. “That’s right, I remember them asking if Phyllis wanted to move to Toledo. Ha, leave Scranton for Toledo? Make me laugh.”
What is Enervate, the Company That Purchased Dunder Mifflin?
Enervate sells products made out of paper, which includes office supplies like janitorial paper, toilet tissue, seat protectors and local newspapers.
Their headquarters is the Truth Teller Tower, which is also home of the struggling local newspaper Toledo Truth Teller.
And this is where “The Paper’s” story begins.

While the sitcom comes from “The Office” creator Greg Daniels and features Oscar Nuñez reprising his role as Oscar Martinez, now the company’s accountant, star Gleeson explained that it’s not a remake.

“It’s the same documentary crew as ‘The Office’ and they followed what happened at Dunder Mifflin and they end up in Toledo. Oscar is still working, but he’s working for a local newspaper,” the actor said on Sept. 3’s TODAY. “There’s a new boss.”
“The Paper” is now streaming on Peacock.
(Peacock, Universal Television and TODAY share the same parent company, NBCUniversal.)

title: U.S. could take lead watching Ukraine buffer zone if peace deal with Russia comes together
summary: If a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine ever comes together, the U.S. could take the lead role in monitoring a large buffer zone inside Ukraine.
story: WASHINGTON — If a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine ever comes together, the United States could take the lead role in monitoring a large buffer zone inside Ukraine envisioned as a way to protect the country from Russia, according to four people familiar with a plan that military officials from Ukraine’s allies, including the United States, have been discussing.

The buffer zone would be a large demilitarized area — the borders of which have not yet been decided — inside what is now Ukraine, dividing Russian and Ukrainian territory within the country. In part because of its technological capabilities, the United States would take the lead in watching the buffer zone, using drones and satellites along with other intelligence capabilities, but it would coordinate with other countries that would also monitor.

The zone could then be secured by troops from one or more non-NATO countries, like Saudi Arabia or even Bangladesh, according to the people familiar with the plan. No U.S. troops would be deployed inside Ukraine, they said. Politico previously reported the general idea of a buffer zone.

Russian President Vladimir Putin would have to agree to any plan for security guarantees for Ukraine, and NATO involvement or even the suggestion of it is a major issue for him, so the planners are taking pains to avoid using NATO forces or anything resembling NATO branding, some of the people familiar with the plan said.

Instead, some of the guarantees would be likely to rely on the troops from non-NATO countries and on a patchwork of bilateral agreements among Ukraine and its allies that would give Ukraine security assurances without involving NATO’s Article V — an attack on one means an attack on all — which amounts to a red line for Moscow.

Any plan is only tentative until Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy agree to one, in addition to the leaders of the countries that would be involved in the security guarantees, including President Donald Trump.

This one has been developed in the wake of Trump’s meeting with Putin in Alaska on Aug. 15. That meeting was initially expected to lead to further talks, possibly direct discussions between Putin and Zelenskyy, but progress toward a peace deal has stalled since then. Still, Ukraine’s allies have gone ahead with their work on the potential security guarantees, which would most likely be key to peace.

On Thursday, members of the group of allies, which is informally known as the “coalition of the willing,” met to potentially formalize aspects of the plan. The meeting was led by France and the United Kingdom, which are also expected to head up the overall effort to provide Ukraine with security after the war’s end.

Zelenskyy wrote on X after the meeting: “We discussed in detail each country’s readiness to make a contribution to ensuring security on land, at sea, in the air, and in cyberspace. We coordinated positions and reviewed elements of security guarantees.”

On Friday, though, Putin rejected the idea of troops from other countries playing any role, saying, “As for possible military contingents in Ukraine — this is one of the primary reasons for drawing Ukraine into NATO. ...  And if decisions are reached that will lead to peace, to a long-term peace, then I simply do not see any sense in their presence on the territory of Ukraine. That’s all. Because if these agreements are reached, let no one doubt that Russia will implement them in full. And we will respect those security guarantees that, of course, must be developed for both Russia and Ukraine. And, I repeat once again, of course, Russia will fulfill the agreement.”

Putin's stance is one of many challenges involved as planning moves forward. There are also tough decisions to be made about what kind of Russian incursions would trigger a response from either Ukraine or the monitoring forces and what kind of response would be allowed. one of the sources said. This person said that the rules of engagement still need to be worked out and that they are likely to be contested during any disagreements after a deal and the buffer are in place.

Along with the buffer zone, it would also be important to guarantee that Russia could not choke off Ukraine’s economy. To that point, Turkey would be responsible for ensuring the unimpeded flow of goods and services on the Black Sea by conducting maritime surveillance of and enforcement in the Bosporus and Dardanelles straits. Shortly after Russia invaded Ukraine, Turkey played a part in securing the maritime corridor that was established to get grain out of Ukraine.

At the Pentagon, talks are being led by Air Force Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, with a broader discussion also centered on deterrence, training and defense industrial cooperation. On the latter front, the United States is discussing with Ukraine a deal that could be worth around $100 billion, under which Kyiv would be able to buy American weapons, while in exchange the United States would get intellectual property rights for the cutting-edge systems the Ukrainians have been developing, according to a U.S. official.
The week after Trump met with Putin, Caine briefed Trump on four options for the security guarantee and recommended the most forward-leaning approach, this official said.
White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt did not address the contours of the plan in a statement to NBC News.
“President Trump is the decision maker,” she wrote. “Out of respect for ongoing diplomatic negotiations, the White House is not going to get ahead of him on these important matters.”
She added: “Anyone anonymously claiming to know what he will or will not support doesn’t know what they are talking about.”
The people familiar with the plan who spoke with NBC News did not say Trump had endorsed or ruled out any of the options.

title: U.S. envoy Mike Huckabee says it's a 'big mistake' to blame Gaza's starvation on Israel
summary: Ambassador Mike Huckabee's stances have hewn closely to the government of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s, even as Trump expresses occasional unease.
story: JERUSALEM — He’s quipped more than once that President Donald Trump misheard Israel’s request for a “Maccabee” — an ancient Jewish warrior — and instead sent a “Huckabee.”
But U.S. Ambassador to Israel Mike Huckabee says his devotion to Israel, and conviction that he is carrying out God’s work in the Holy Land, is no joke.

“We share a value system that is rooted deeply in a biblical understanding of a worldview that says that the individual is important,” the Baptist minister, 70, said of Israel and the U.S. during a wide-ranging interview with NBC News last week. “That is, in my mind, the very essence of Western civilization. And it is on that platform that both the United States and Israel are built and that puts us in a very, very special relationship.”

Huckabee’s strong ties to Israel were forged during more than 100 visits to the country before his appointment and are grounded in a belief that God commanded Jewish sovereignty over their biblical homeland.

His ambassadorship could end up being deeply consequential. Not only was it a win for the evangelical Christian community, a vital part of Trump’s base, but it was also a boon to Israel’s far-right government as it faces unprecedented criticism for its war in the Gaza Strip. His stances in just over six months in Israel have hewn closely to the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s, even as Trump expresses occasional unease with the close U.S. ally’s conduct.
In July, images of badly emaciated children in Gaza prompted Trump to acknowledge “real starvation” in the enclave — a break with Netanyahu, who maintained there was no starvation.

The following month, on Aug. 22, the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification, the world’s leading body on hunger, officially declared famine in part of northern Gaza, including Gaza City. For months before that announcement, international humanitarian organizations had warned that the trickle of aid Israel had allowed into the enclave wasn’t nearly enough to feed its population of 2.1 million.

title: Tax scandal sinks U.K. deputy leader in huge blow to embattled PM Keir Starmer
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.
story: LONDON — Somehow, it keeps getting worse for Keir Starmer.

The British Prime Minister was already in the mire: His economy is barely growing, ascendant critics assail him from the left and right, and his popularity has tanked to historic levels just a year after a landslide victory.
And on Friday Starmer suffered perhaps his most significant setback yet when his influential deputy resigned after admitting she underpaid 40,000 pounds (around $54,000) in property taxes.

Angela Rayner, 45, has not always agreed with Starmer but has been a key figure in his Labour Party, seen as a counterweight voice for its disgruntled left-wing against their leader's centrist conservatism.

After months of press speculation, Rayner admitted this week that she failed to pay enough property taxes — known as “stamp duty.” She said she believed she had followed the rules, and was tripped up by her “complex living arrangements,” including her 2023 divorce and son with special educational needs.
All this played out while she served as the government’s housing secretary as well as its deputy leader.

She referred herself to the independent adviser on ministerial standards, Laurie Magnus, who acts as a watchdog appointed by the prime minister. Rayner promptly resigned her role as deputy prime minister and housing minister after his report was delivered Friday.
"I take full responsibility for this error," she said in a letter to Starmer, accepting she "did not meet the highest standards in relation to my recent property purchase."

She said that while "it was never my intention to do anything other than pay the right amount," she "must also consider the significant toll that the ongoing pressure of the media is taking on my family."

Magnus' report agreed that Rayner had acted "in good faith," believing that she was paying the correct amount of tax during the purchase of her 800,000 pound seaside apartment in Hove, on the south coast of England, in May. However he said that Rayner broke the Ministerial Code (a set of rules and standards for people in the government to follow) because she did not follow her solicitors' advice to seek specific tax guidance.
Had she done so, Magnus said, she would have known the correct amount was 70,000 pounds rather than the 30,000 she paid.

"I believe Ms. Rayner has acted with integrity and with a dedicated and exemplary commitment to public service," he said.  But he faulted her "unfortunate failure" to pay her taxes correctly, particularly given she was minister for housing at the time.
Tax experts say Rayner will likely now face a fine of up to 12,000 pounds from His Majesty’s Revenue and Customs, Britain’s tax authority.
Starmer under pressure

In a handwritten note, Starmer said he was "very sad" that Rayner's tenure had "ended in this way," but said it was "right" that she had acted on the conclusion of her ethics report despite knowing it was "very painful" for her.

Kemi Badenoch, leader of the opposition Conservative Party, reacted to her resignation by accusing Starmer of having "no principle, no backbone" and saying that "questions remain" about what he knew, and when.

Just 14 months ago, Starmer won a historic landslide victory against a Conservative Party whose 14-year rule had ended in scandal and widespread public disdain. But polls suggested that his victory owed as much to his opponent’s toxic image as any ringing enthusiasm for his own platform.

Whereas his predecessor as party leader, Jeremy Corbyn, had sought to take Labour back to its leftist roots, Starmer was more in the mold of Tony Blair: relatively progressive social values mixed with economic conservatism that critics say departed little from his right-wing opponents.
That alleged caution has been met with opposition from multiple sides.

Many on the left see him as maddeningly unimaginative in the face of a long-term economic malaise that they say requires radical, progressive action. And the right see him as too soft on immigration, most notably the “small boats” crisis that continues to see tens of thousands of asylum seekers cross the English Channel each year.

Immigration is now the top priority for voters, polls show, and opinion surveys are now led by Nigel Farage, the friend and ally of American President Donald Trump, who leads the Reform political party.
If he becomes prime minister after the next election scheduled for 2029, Farage has promised to enact a mass deportation scheme removing 600,000 undocumented migrants from Britain.
A teenage mother who grew up in socialized housing in the northern town of Stockport, Rayner is widely seen as holding an everyman touch that resonated with voters in a way Starmer never has.

She was viewed as a vital weapon in Labour’s defense against the rising working-class anger being so successfully harnessed by Farage — and therefore her exit represents a powerful loss for the government.
Rayner’s departure is doubly significant because she also quit from the role of deputy party leader, which is chosen by the party members, rather than Starmer himself.
This means a more outspoken left-wing lawmaker could be voted into the role — increasing the pressure on Starmer to veer left in search of a solution.

title: Israeli reservists say they'd rather go to jail than serve in the assault on Gaza City
summary: In Israel, some military reservists are refusing a call up because they do not want to fight in Gaza, part of which is facing famine.
story: JERUSALEM — He was once proud to be part of the Israeli military, eager to defend his homeland after the Hamas-led terrorist attack of Oct. 7, 2023.
Today, Max Kresch, 29, refuses to serve in Gaza.
The Israeli American veteran combat medic is among a growing number of reservists questioning the war’s end game and refusing to fight if called to serve, risking jail.

“The war right now is a direct threat to our future. It’s a direct threat to the future of Israelis, of civilians, of our own values,” said Kresch, whose mandatory military service ended in 2018, and who served on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon during the current war.

Amid widespread global outrage about renewed military operations in northern Gaza and large-scale protests in Israel calling for a deal to free the hostages still being held, NBC News spoke to several reservists including Kresch, all of whom have served but do not want to fight any more in Gaza.

title: Tax scandal sinks U.K. deputy leader in huge blow to embattled PM Keir Starmer
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.
story: LONDON — Somehow, it keeps getting worse for Keir Starmer.

The British Prime Minister was already in the mire: His economy is barely growing, ascendant critics assail him from the left and right, and his popularity has tanked to historic levels just a year after a landslide victory.
And on Friday Starmer suffered perhaps his most significant setback yet when his influential deputy resigned after admitting she underpaid 40,000 pounds (around $54,000) in property taxes.

Angela Rayner, 45, has not always agreed with Starmer but has been a key figure in his Labour Party, seen as a counterweight voice for its disgruntled left-wing against their leader's centrist conservatism.

After months of press speculation, Rayner admitted this week that she failed to pay enough property taxes — known as “stamp duty.” She said she believed she had followed the rules, and was tripped up by her “complex living arrangements,” including her 2023 divorce and son with special educational needs.
All this played out while she served as the government’s housing secretary as well as its deputy leader.

She referred herself to the independent adviser on ministerial standards, Laurie Magnus, who acts as a watchdog appointed by the prime minister. Rayner promptly resigned her role as deputy prime minister and housing minister after his report was delivered Friday.
"I take full responsibility for this error," she said in a letter to Starmer, accepting she "did not meet the highest standards in relation to my recent property purchase."

She said that while "it was never my intention to do anything other than pay the right amount," she "must also consider the significant toll that the ongoing pressure of the media is taking on my family."

Magnus' report agreed that Rayner had acted "in good faith," believing that she was paying the correct amount of tax during the purchase of her 800,000 pound seaside apartment in Hove, on the south coast of England, in May. However he said that Rayner broke the Ministerial Code (a set of rules and standards for people in the government to follow) because she did not follow her solicitors' advice to seek specific tax guidance.
Had she done so, Magnus said, she would have known the correct amount was 70,000 pounds rather than the 30,000 she paid.
